content.html_value:
The Origin of Life

The Biological Sciences, as well as Physics and Chemistry (History Tracers Editors. Physics; History Tracers Editors. Chemistry), transcend the boundaries of planet Earth. When studying the birth of galaxies, for example, we can identify chemical elements that are essential for life (Gibson, Carl H., et al., , pp. 10).

Like any science, Biology is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps, part, dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that part before proceeding (History Tracers Editors. First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or Biology before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-Biology or pre-Biology, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge). In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Biology and proto-Biology, gradually connecting them to Biology through mathematics.
Chapter 1: The Origin of What We Observe

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: In this text, we take a journey back in time to understand what current measurements reveal about the universe’s past.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good vs. evil, left vs. right, matter vs. energy, up vs. down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up...
